description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Cooperation among different jurisdictional entities (e.g. treaties or agreements among countries or provinces)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: December 15, 2020: With Bulletin N. 317, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health attended a meeting with other European States including Belgium, France, Germany, Luxembourg, The Netherlands, Spain and Switzerland. The aim of the meeting was to discuss the vaccination campaign and the need to coordinate efforts for the safe and efficient use of the COVID-19 vaccine. During the meeting, the Ministers agreed to promote the coordination of the vaccination campaign and the rapid sharing of information between national and international authorities. Furthermore, they agreed on a fast sharing of information and experiences in the field of pharmacovigilance. The Ministers also committed to fight disinformation and fake news over the vaccination campaign. Finally, the Health Ministers agreed on the need to ensure a clear and transparent communication to the population about vaccines.

description: Announced on November 12, 2020, the Luxembourg Ministry of Education stated that the upper classes of secondary education would at the same time switch to the dual education model. Starting on November 30, 2020, the alternation can be daily or weekly and can occur either by dividing the pupils of each class into two groups A and B; or by alternating face-to-face and distance learning phases for the whole class. The final decision should be taken by each Institution.

description: Announced on February 12, 2021, The Luxembourg Minister of Education, Children and Youth allowed primary and secondary schools to open but under very strict conditions. For primary schools, It includes mandatory masks from students in the second cycle, there will be more testing, with everyone who was in quarantine requiring a test to return to school (antigen test). For secondary schools the pupils will return to alternate between two groups A/B schooling, exam schedules and study material for final years will be reduced of 15% and deadlines for final test will be adjusted.

All children aged 4 to 12 as well as the staff of basic schools and relay houses are concerned to use the rapid self-tests. These are carried out by the Large Scale Testing mobile teams and start on March 29, 2021 until April 2, 2021.

description:
Announced on February 12, 2021, The Luxembourg Minister of Education, Children and Youth allowed primary and secondary schools to open but under very strict conditions. For primary schools, It includes mandatory masks from students in the second cycle, there will be more testing, with everyone who was in quarantine requiring a test to return to school (antigen test). For secondary schools the pupils will return to alternate between two groups A/B schooling, exam schedules and study material for final years will be reduced of 15% and deadlines for final test will be adjusted.
 UPDATE: From May 1st, 2021, students will begin using self-administered rapid tests to stop coronavirus infections from spreading unchecked. All students and teachers will receive one such test a week.

description: Announced on Dezember 4, 2020, the Prime Minister, the Minister of State and the Minister of Health presented the key elements of the vaccination plan in Luxembourg. The vaccination strategy is structured around 5 pillars and includes several components, including allocation, supply, communication, post-marketing effects monitoring of vaccine products. At the time of the development of the strategy, Luxembourg committed itself for 1.3 million doses of vaccine with which it will be possible to vaccinate more than 800,000 people, since some of these vaccines require the administration of 2 doses. Vaccine candidates: include AstraZeneca, Sanofi GSK, Johnson&Johnson, BioNTech/Pfizer, CureVac and Moderna.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

type_vac_purchase: Preorder with the option of expanding the order
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Announced on December 4, 2020, a working group, set up under the International Crisis Staff at the Minister of Health, developed the vaccination strategy in Luxembourg and stated that vaccination centers will constitute the structures to efficiently and effectively control the vaccination in the country. This means that only vaccination centers will have the function to storage the Covid-19 vaccines.

description: Announced on December 4, 2020, the National Government of Luxembourg and the Ministry of Health, stated that the supply of vaccines in multi-dose containers will be supported by mobile teams of the Ministry of Health to better reach people with no conditions of going to a vaccination center, e.g. elderly people. In addition to it, the mobile teams provide the structure and equipment to carry out vaccination, as well as IT and logistic support. They are composed of a team leader medical officer and an administrative and logistical assistant (army and the Fire and Rescue Corps).

description: On December 28, 2020, the National Government of Luxembourg and the Ministry of Health announced the first two persons to get the vaccine in accordance with the strategy plan of vaccination. About 800 people from the hospital sector, respectively 200 people per acute hospital facility will be vaccinated during December 28 and 29. On December 30, 2020, the vaccinations will be for staff of housing facilities for the elderly - with 400 vaccinations also planned. In addition, paramedics transporting COVID-19 patients were offered vaccination during these three days. All these categories pertence to the priority group 1.

description:
By the end of the week of 17 February 2021, invitations will be sent out to those covered by phase 2 of the vaccination campaign.
Following the decision of the Government Council of 29 January, the people concerned are residents aged 75 and over, starting with the oldest (phase 2a), as well as people who are highly vulnerable due to a pre-existing health condition (phase 2b). The diseases in this context are as follows:

Trisomy 21, adults
Solid organ transplants, including people on a waiting list
Hematopoietic stem cell transplants within the first 6 months or under immunosuppressive treatment
Cancer or malignant hemopathy undergoing treatment (chemotherapy, radiotherapy, immunotherapy)
Congenital immunodeficiencies

description: Announced on March 12, 2021, The Luxembourg Ministry of Health stated the temporary suspension, starting on March 9, 2021, of vaccinations with the lot of COVID-19 Vaccine AstraZeneca, due to unpredicted side effects. As a precautionary principle, this lot will be in quarantine until more evidence can show more safety regarding the vaccine. UPDATE: Originally the AstraZeneca vaccine was suspended due to undesirable side effects. Announced on March 18, 2021, The Luxembourg Ministry of Health confirms the resumption of vaccinations with AstraZeneca, because its benefits far outweigh the risks of the side effects. Starting on March 19, 2021 it will again be part of the vaccination campaign.

description: Announced on March 12, 2021, The Luxembourg Ministry of Health decided that the third phase of the vaccination strategy will begin on March 19, 2021 and  prioritise residents belonging to the age category of 70 to 74 years, starting with the oldest (phase 3a), as well as persons significantly vulnerable due to their state of health (phase 3b). The diseases in question for vulnerable people are immunodeficiency, chronic respiratory disease, cardiovascular disease, Major neuro-cognitive deficit, Chronic renal failure on dialysis,  Child-Pugh stage B or C cirrhosis and Morbid obesity (body mass index > 40 kg/m2).

description: Announced on March 30, 2021, The Luxembourg Ministry of Health decided that the fourth phase of the vaccination strategy will begin on March 31, 2021 and prioritise residents belonging to the age category of 65 to 69 years, starting with the oldest (phase 4a), as well as moderately vulnerable people, due to their pre-existing medical condition (stage 4b). The diseases in question for vulnerable people are Diabetes with or without insulin, with cardio-neuro-vascular complications, Complicated arterial hypertension, with sequelae of stroke or associated heart disease and neuromuscular disease with clinical repercussions. They will receive an invitation by post to make an appointment at one of the vaccination centers.

description: Announced on September 14, 2021, The Luxembourg National Government, the Ministry of Health and Minister of Family, Integration and the Greater Region followed the recommendation of the CSMI to administer 3rd dose ("booster") of vaccination against the coronavirus for: people aged over 75 at home, for the elderly in a residential structure without age limit and people on dialysis. On September 17, 2021 begins the first invitations to register online and subsequently take the jab. Participants can be vaccinated at the  Victor Hugo vaccination center or by specific private doctors. UPDATE: Originally, only people aged over 75 and people on dialysis, were allowed to take the “booster” jab of the vaccination against the coronavirus. Announced on November 9, 2021, The Luxembourg National Government and the Ministry of Health stated that from November 8, 2021, a booster dose of coronavirus vaccination may be administered 	to people aged 65 and over, regardless of their residence (accommodation structure or at home), health professionals and medical and dental assistants. The vaccine used for the booster is an mRNA vaccine.

description:
Announced on November 9, 2021, The Luxembourg National Government and the Ministry of Health stated that from November 8, 2021, a booster dose of coronavirus vaccination may be administered to people aged 65 and over, regardless of their residence (accommodation structure or at home), health professionals and medical dental assistants, as well as for the elderly in a residential structure without age limit and people on dialysis. The vaccine used for the booster is an mRNA vaccine. People will receive an invitation by post and need to be registered on the website. 
 UPDATE: Originally, a booster dose against coronavirus was only allowed for people aged 65 and over and for health professionals. Announced on November 19, 2021 at a press conference, the Luxembourg National Government and the Minister of Health will roll out Covid-19 booster shots to all adults aged 18 and over. Starting on November 19, 2021, they will be able to take an additional, voluntary jab six months after their second dose.

description: Announced on November 29, 2021, The Luxembourg National Government and the Ministry of Health followed the recommendation of the CSMI to vaccinate vulnerable children aged 5 to 11 as well as those in regular contact with vulnerable people, with mRNA vaccine from Pfizer-Biontech (Cominarty). The vulnerabilities in question are: respiratory and cardiac pathologies, severe congenital or acquired immunosuppression, metabolic, neurological, and renal Diseases, and Chromosomal abnormalities including trisomy 21. UPDATE: Originally, only vulnerable children aged from 5 to 11 were allowed to take the Cominarty Vaccine. Announced on December 23, 2021, The Luxembourg Ministry of State and the Ministry of Health stated that now all children between 5 and 11 years old can take the jab of Comirnaty (Pfizer and BioNTech) in the 3 vaccination centres Victor Hugo, Esch-Belval and Ettelbruck.

description:
Luxemburg is extending the duration of the curfew, from 11pm to 6am, until February, 21. With still some exceptions: 
1.	with a view to their professional activity or to training or teaching 
2.	for medical consultations or the provision of health care which cannot be postponed or provided at a distance 
3.	for the purchase of medicines or health products 
4.	for compelling family reasons, for assistance and care for vulnerable or precarious persons or for childcare 
5.	in response to a judicial, police or administrative summons  
6.	to or from a railway station or airport in connection with a trip abroad 
7.	in connection with transit on the motorway network
8.	 within a radius of one kilometre of the place of residence for the needs of pets 
9.	in case of force majeure or situation of necessity

description: Luxemburg is declaring a state of crisis on 17 March, which gives the Government the possibility to set up emergency measures in order to face the crisis. Thus, a regulatory and legal framework is established, in line with the Luxembourg Constitution: the scope covered by this Article is limited to measures which cannot be taken in good time through the normal legislative procedure. The Chamber of Deputies can, at every moment, suspend or revoke the state of crisis: Parliamentary control is this fully guaranteed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Taking effect on 18th March 2020, the prime minister of Luxembourg announced that all citizens from EU, UK and the Schengen Area are only allowed to travel, if they are returning to their homes (Article 14). For example, this policy restricts travel in the border with Germany.

description: Luxemburg banned third-country nationals to enter the territory of the Grand Duchy. The restriction was put in place, initially, for a one month period starting on March 18, 2020.  There are several exemptions from this ban, including for  Belgian, French, and German cross-border workers. UPDATE: In agreement with the European Union, Luxembourg reopens its borders to all travellers on 15 June UPDATE: In agreement with the European Union, Luxembourg reopens its borders to all travellers on 15 June
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On 29 May 2020, the Luxembourg government, together with lux- Airport, is launching a pilot project aimed at testing passengers on landing flights at Luxembourg Airport. This policy has an initial period of one month. Anyone arriving in Luxembourg by air will receive a voucher valid for several days to be tested in a medical analysis laboratory of their choice. Alternatively, a test station that lux- Airport has installed in the terminal allows passengers arriving from other airports to be tested directly on site. In the event of a positive result, the usual isolation procedure is applied, as well as a tracing of contacts in Luxembourg.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Taking effect on 18th March 2020, the prime minister of Lexembourg announced that  the regularisation of stay for all those having : Short-term and long-term visas; Temporary residence permits; Residence card and Residence permits, is prolonged until the end of the crisis with no need to appear in person to update these papers. UPDATE: On 24 June 2020, the Ministry of Foreign and European Affairs wishes to inform the end of the state of crisis.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description: On 24 June 2020, the Ministry of Foreign and European Affairs extends temporaily: 1) the residence permit of those third-country nationals who arrived at a specific date in the country, and 2) the visa of those their-country nationals which need a short-term visa or were travelling through the country at there time. This policy was instituted as a provisory measure, as the state of crisis is no longer into force.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description: On 24 June 2020, the Ministry of Foreign and European Affairs extends the period within third-country nationals must apply for the residence permit from 3 to 6 months. It applies only for third-country nationals which arrived between 1 January and 31 July 2020 in Luxembourg. For residence permits which expire after March 1, 2020: the stay is extended until August 31, 2020. The stay of third-country nationals with short-stay visa and those not subject to the visa requirement and whose stay has just exceeded 90 days after March 1, 2020: the stay is regularised until July 31, 2020. This was a temporary measure adopted after the end of the state of crisis.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description: On 11 June 2020, the government of Luxembourg acted in favour of the  European Commission's recommendation to extend the restriction on non-essential travel into the EU until 30 June 2020, and which sets out an approach for a gradual lifting of the restriction on non-essential travel into the EU as of 1 July 2020.

description: On 1 July, the Government of Luxembourg acted in favour of European Commission's recommendation on the temporary restriction of non-essential travels for third-country nationals until 15 September 2020 inclusive. The list of exceptions from this rule: Algeria, Australia, Canada,Georgia, Japan, Montenegro, Morocco, New Zealand, Rwanda, Serbia, South Korea, Thailand, Tunisia,Uruguay, and China (if reciprocal).
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Announced on July 17, 2020, The Luxembourg National Government stated that the exception list of banned countries is updated by deleting , with effect from July 17, 2020, Montenegro und Serbia. Therefore, third-country nationals residing in Montenegro and Serbia will no longer be authorised to enter the territory of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg. Restrictions for third-country nationals remain in place until September 15, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Announced on August 7, 2020, The Luxembourg National Government bans people with residence in Algeria from traveling to Luxembourg as of August 8, 2020. Restrictions for third-country nationals remain in place until September 15, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Announced on July 17, 2020, The Luxembourg National Government stated that from August 12, 2020 third-country nationals aged 11 or over who wish to travel by air to Luxembourg from a country not included in the exception list must present the negative result of a biological test for Covid-19 before boarding. The test must have been carried out less than 48 hours before the flight. All temporary entry restrictions for third-country nationals on the territory of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg shall end on September 15, 2020
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Announced on August 14, 2020, The Luxembourg National Government stated that the exception list of countries which are banned to enter in the territory is updated by deleting Morocco, with effect from August 14, 2020. Therefore, third-country nationals residing Morocco will no longer be authorised to enter the territory of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg. Restrictions for third-country nationals remain in place until September 15, 2020. From now, the exception list has Australia, Canada, China, Georgia, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, South Korea, Thailand, Tunisia, and Uruguay.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Announced on August 14, 2020, The Luxembourg State offers residents the possibility to undergo a free PCR test upon their return from a trip or journey abroad, starting on August 14, 2020. The concerned people should submit an application online in the MyGuichet.lu to get tested in one of the vaccination centres and the test result will be informed by SMS.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Announced on August 21, 2020, The Luxembourg Ministry of Foreign and European Affairs stated that now the period relating to the obligation of third-country nationals aged eleven not appearing on the exception list of banned countries to present a negative result of a covid test is extended to 72 hours as from August 21, 2020. Originally they must present a negative result of a covid test within 48 hours at the boarding.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Announced on September 14, 2020, The Luxembourg Ministry of Foreign and European Affairs stated that, from September 14, 2020, short-stay visits of an EU citizen family member will be exempt from travel restrictions to the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg. Considered as family members are spouse or registered partner; the direct descendant of the EU citizen or his/her spouse/registered partner, if the child is under 21 years of age.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: On 1 July, the Government of Luxembourg acted in favour of European Commission's recommendation on the temporary restriction of non-essential travels for third-country nationals until 15 September 2020 inclusive. The list of exceptions from this rule: Algeria, Australia, Canada,Georgia, Japan, Montenegro, Morocco, New Zealand, Rwanda, Serbia, South Korea, Thailand, Tunisia,Uruguay, and China (if reciprocal). UPDATE: Originally all temporary entry restrictions for third-country nationals on the territory of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg shall end on September 15, 2020. Announced on September 14, 2020, The Luxembourg Ministry of Foreign and European Affairs extended the restrictions on immigration until December 31, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On 1 July 2020, the government council together with the prime minister of Luxembourg approved a draft which follows the recommendation of the European Union on the temporary restriction of non-essential travel to the EU for third-country nationals until 15 September 2020. UPDATE: Originally all temporary entry restrictions for third-country nationals on the territory of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg shall end on September 15, 2020. Announced on September 14, 2020, The Luxembourg Ministry of Foreign and European Affairs extended the restrictions on immigration until December 31, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Announced on July 17, 2020, The Luxembourg National Government stated that the exception list of banned countries is updated by deleting , with effect from July 17, 2020, Montenegro und Serbia. Therefore, third-country nationals residing in Montenegro and Serbia will no longer be authorised to enter the territory of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg. Restrictions for third-country nationals remain in place until September 15, 2020. UPDATE: Originally all temporary entry restrictions for third-country nationals on the territory of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg shall end on September 15, 2020. description: Announced on October 12, 2020, The Luxembourg State offers a free COVID-19 test to cross-border workers after a trip or stay abroad. Thus, this offer is no longer limited to Luxembourg residents only. To benefit from this free test as a cross-border worker, you must: reside in Germany, Belgium or France; and have a Luxembourg social security number (CNS) (13-digit matricule); and be returning from a trip or tourist stay abroad. The policy in question started on October 9, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Migrant workers (please note their occupation in the text entry where applicable)

description: Luxemburg is enforcing bans on third-country nationals to enter the territory. Citizens of third-countries may not enter the Grand Duchy until December 31st 2020. Exceptions are made for citizens of the EU and associated with the Schengen area, along with residents of those following third countries: Australia, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, South Korea, Singapore, Thailand, Uruguay, China/Hong Kong/ Macao
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Announced on November 7, 2020, The Luxembourg Ministry of Foreign Affairs stated that the exception list of banned countries is updated by deleting Canada, Georgia and Tunisia, with effect from November 9, 2020. Therefore, third-country nationals residing Canada, Georgia or Tunisia will no longer be authorised to enter the territory of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg. Restrictions for third-country nationals remain in place until December 31, 2020 and the countries with no restrictions to enter the territory of Luxembourg are: Australia, China, South Korea, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, Thailand, Uruguay and Singapore.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_what: All Foreign Nationals (Foreign Residents + Foreign Travelers)

description: Announced on December 20, 2020, The Luxembourg Ministry of Foreign Affairs is temporarily banning passenger flights from the UK from midnight today for at least 24 hours as a precaution and pending new conclusive scientific knowledge of the new detected strain of coronavirus.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Announced on December 20, 2020, The Luxembourg Ministry of Foreign Affairs is temporarily banning passenger flights from the UK from midnight today for at least 24 hours as a precaution and pending new conclusive scientific knowledge of the new detected strain of coronavirus. UPDATE: Originally all flights from the UK were banned due to the discovery of a new strain of the coronavirus. Announced on December 23, 2020, The Luxembourg Ministry of Health and Ministry of Foreign and European Affairs lift the temporary restriction of scheduled passenger flights to and from the United Kingdom. Although, passengers returning to Luxembourg must be in possession of a negative PCR test dating less than 48 hours or between 48 and 72 hours.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Announced on August 14, 2020, The Luxembourg National Government stated that the exception list of banned countries is updated by deleting Morocco, with effect from August 14, 2020. Therefore, third-country nationals residing Morocco will no longer be authorised to enter the territory of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg. Restrictions for third-country nationals remain in place until September 15, 2020. UPDATE: Originally, there was an exception list of third-national countries that could travel to Luxembourg. Announced on December 29, 2020, The Luxembourg National Government stated that from now on the list have changed and there are new third-national countries which may no longer enter in the territory.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

Therefore, third-country nationals residing Canada, Georgia or Tunisia will no longer be authorised to enter the territory of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg. Restrictions for third-country nationals remain in place until December 31, 2020 and the countries with no restrictions to enter the territory of Luxembourg are: Australia, China, South Korea, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, Thailand, Uruguay and Singapore. UPDATE: Originally this policy should end on December 31, 2020. Announced on February 8, 2021, all restrictions on the entry of third-country nationals into the territory of Luxembourg are valid until 31 March 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_what: All Foreign Nationals (Foreign Residents + Foreign Travelers)

description: On 1 July 2020, the government council together with the prime minister of Luxembourg approved a draft which follows the recommendation of the European Union on the temporary restriction of non-essential travel to the EU for third-country nationals until 15 September 2020. UPDATE: Originally, there was an exception list of third-national countries that could travel to Luxembourg. Announced on December 29, 2020, The Luxembourg National Government stated that from now on the list have changed and there are new third-national countries which may no longer enter in the territory.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Announced on January 1st, 2021, The Luxembourg National government stated that third-country nationals residing in the UK, including UK nationals not falling under the provisions of the Withdrawal Agreement, will be subject to the same temporary restrictions as nationals of other third countries as regards entry into the territory of Luxembourg. From January 1st, 2021, all third-country nationals aged 11 or older, including persons holding a temporary residence permit or a residence permit, wishing to travel to Luxembourg by air from a third country that does not feature on the list of third countries exempt from the temporary restrictions on non-essential travel to the EU, must present, before boarding, the negative result of a biological examination for SARS-CoV-2 viral RNA carried out less than 72 hours before the flight.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Luxemburg, like other European countries, is strengthening its borders starting Friday, January 29th. Entrances by plane from people who were from at least 72 hours abroad need to present a negative PCR test.
Exceptions are made for cross-border workers.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Announced on January 26, 2021, The Luxembourg Ministry of Foreign and European Affairs and the Ministry of Health informs that regardless of nationality, aged 6 or over, wishing to travel by air to the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, must present upon boarding the negative result (on paper or electronic document) of a test that detects SARS-CoV-2 nucleic acid, or of a rapid antigen test, performed up to 72 hours before the flight. This policy starts on January 29, 2021 and ends on March 31, 2021. The list of third countries whose residents are currently allowed to enter Luxembourg contains Australia, South Korea, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, and Thailand.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_gen: People of a certain age (please note age range in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description: Announced on February 8, 2020, The Luxembourg National Government stated that Japan will be excluded from the exception list of countries allowed to enter in the Grand Duchy territory. Starting on February 8, 2021, therefore, third-country nationals with residency in Japan will no longer be able to travel to Luxembourg until March 31, 2021. The updated list of third-country nationals who are still authorised to enter the territory is Australia, China, South Korea, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore and Thailand.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Announced on August 14, 2020, The Luxembourg National Government stated that the exception list of banned countries is updated by deleting Morocco, with effect from August 14, 2020. Therefore, third-country nationals residing Morocco will no longer be authorised to enter the territory of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg. Restrictions for third-country nationals remain in place until September 15, 2020. UPDATE: Originally all temporary entry restrictions for third-country nationals on the territory of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg shall end on March 31, 2021. description: Announced on Mai 3, 2021, The Luxembourg National Government stated that from 1 May to 15 May 2021 regardless of the means of transport and regardless of nationality and age any person who stayed in India during the 14 days prior to his or her arrival on Luxembourg territory must undergo a nucleic acid amplification tests of SARS-CoV-2 viral RNA - PCR, TMA or LAMP. Upon arrival in the Grand Duchy, the persons concerned are placed in strict quarantine for 7 days with the obligation to undergo a second nucleic acid amplification tests of SARS-CoV-2 viral RNA.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Police

description: Announced on June 4, 2021, The Luxembourg Ministry of Health and Foreign Affairs stated that regardless of the means of transport and regardless of the length of stay in the UK anyone traveling from the UK to Luxembourg must submit a negative SARS-CoV-2 viral RNA (PCR) test during the 14 days prior to his or her arrival on Luxembourg territory. Upon arrival those affected also must be in strict quarantine for seven days, with the obligation to undergo a second test from the sixth day of quarantine. This policy started on June 4, 2021 and ends June 30, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Police

Upon arrival those affected also must be in strict quarantine for seven days, with the obligation to undergo a second test from the sixth day of quarantine. description: Announced on June 12, 2021, The Luxembourg Ministry of Health and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs stated new health measures applicable  for all travel by air, given the improvement in the situation of the coronavirus. Thus, from June 13 until 30 September, 2021 any person from the age of 6, wishing to travel to the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg must present at boarding either a vaccination certificate attesting to a complete vaccination schedule, a recovery certificate issued by a doctor or a national authority of a Member State of the European Union, or a negative result of a nucleic acid amplification test RNA (PCR, TMA or LAMP) carried out less than 72 hours before the flight. The exception list of third-national countries which do not need to present the health certificates above is: Australia, China, South Korea, Israel, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore and Thailand.

description: Announced on April 9, 2020, The Luxembourg Ministry of Health with a committee of experts representing various health stakeholders set up a patient remote monitoring tool, Maela, which since March 30, 2020 has been used in all hospitals, the Château de Colpach convalescence center, and as a platform of the Department of Health. This device makes it possible to remotely monitor all patients who test positive for COVID-19; both those who are in isolation at home, and those who have just been discharged from hospital. Its enrollment is voluntary for all people.

description: Announced on October 22, 2020, the Luxembourg Ministry of Health stated that the Health Inspection's contact tracing unit has adapted its mode of operation in order to increase its responsiveness in making contacts. The adaptations start on October 23, 2020 and are the following: If you test positive for COVID-19 or have symptoms: self-isolate,  and If you were in high-risk contact with someone who tested positive for COVID-19: Self-quarantine.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
As of October 24th 2020 the government announced that in order to manage the contact tracing it is essential not to call the hotline right away, but to wait for the Contact Tracing-team to get in touch. 

For this two declaration forms are online starting 10/24/2020. 
If you have been tested positive for Covid-19: You must immediately go into isolation, without waiting for a call from the Contact Tracing team.

The Contact Tracing-team has been informed of your result. While waiting for their call, you can help them trace and identify people who have had high-risk contact with you. In order to do so, you need to download the declaration form via the website and send to the E-mail address indicated on it.

If you've been in contact with someone who tested positive for COVID-19: You must self-quarantine. To receive the required documents, you must complete the form and return it to the indicated email address. You must indicate the first and last name of the positive person, or the reference number of the file, if the COVID-19 positive person provided it to you.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Who a person has come into contact with over time
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Announced on November 7, 2020, the Luxembourg Ministry of Health, in order to simplify and speed up contact tracing by the Contact Tracing team, stated that the tracing procedure has been optimized via the declaration forms. After sending the form, persons who have tested positive will receive a SMS with more informations and a link with the dedicated website of the Health Inspectorate covidtracing.public.lu.

description: On May 8, 2020, the government announced that cross-border workers will receive 50 surgical masks for free. Especially for that purpose, the army of Luxembourg will open 12 mask distribution centers throughout the country for a period of two weeks. Cross-Border workers, who will receive vouchers by mail, can collect the masks between the May 11 and May 24, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Migrant workers (please note their occupation in the text entry where applicable)

description: On May 4th 2020, the Prime minister of Luxembourg, Xavier Bettel, announced that every resident will receive 50 surgical masks for free. This measure is part of the exit strategy starting from May 11th 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On May 29th 2020, a covid-testing facility was opened at Lux-Airport. Passengers arriving in Luxembourg can get tested. The testing facility is part of a one-month pilot project and will be used to assess the benefits of covid-health testing in the country.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On the 25 March 2020, the Luxembourg Ministry of Health opens an Advanced Care Center in the commune Ettelbruck. The third one from 4 test centers, is designed to accommodate patients with and without signs of Covid-19 and to provide information and healthcare for multiple patients in parallel, in order to limit waiting times. UPDATE: Originally there was an Advanced Care center in the Commune Ettelbruck. Announced on May 29, 2020, the Luxembourg's Ministry of Health declares the closure of this advanced care center.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Announce don December 31, 2020, The Luxembourg National Government stated that from January 2, 2021, rapid antigen tests will be offered to all passengers arriving at Luxembourg airport. The tests are mainly aimed at travellers returning from holiday destinations and all passengers will receive a voucher for the test. This service is voluntary and free of charge.

description: Announced on January 22, 2021, the Ministry of Economy together with the Ministry of Health of Luxembourg will cover expenses to the Project of “Large Scale Testing - Phase 2” by financing the acquisition of test equipments, as well as for the management of the project (awareness of the general public, execution and monitoring), with 60 million euros. The budget was obtained from the European Initiative “REACT-EU”.

description: Announced on May 19, 2021, the Luxembourg Ministry of Health stated that in parallel with the testing-strategy, the government will distribute starter testing kits to the working population: Municipal civil service (from 15 May); civil service (from 17 May), private companies, self-employed, seasonal workers and public institutions (from 17 May) and European and international civil services (from 18 May).

description: Announced on May 12, 2021, the Ministry of Health and Luxembourg Pharmacist’s Union allow pharmacies to perform and certify rapid antigen tests (RATs) starting on May 17, 2021. After the test, whose costs are charged to the person involved, the participants receive a certificate that can be used as a proof of a negative result required for certain trips, activities or entries (restaurants, bars, cafes, etc.).

description: Announced on June 1st, 2021, the Luxembourg Ministry of Health and the Grand-Ducal Fire and Rescue Corps (CGDIS) stated that from 1 June 2021, the emergency services of the Luxembourg Hospital Center (CHL) and Robert Schuman Hospitals, Kirchberg Hospital site (HK), will provide parallel call duty in the Center region on working holidays. This policy aims to reduce patient waiting times for emergency treatment.

description: Announced on July 8, 2021, the Luxembourg Ministry oh Health presented the pilot project for a multidisciplinary long-COVID care network, which starts on August 1, 2021 and ends on February 1, 2021. The pilot project was developed to respond adequately to the worrying emergence of this new public health problem.

description: Announced on August 5, 2021, The Luxembourg Ministry of Health inaugurated the new medical care center at the centre of Luxembourg. Starting on September 2, 2021, the medical center maintain the continuity of medical care, excluding emergencies, when the offices of general practitioners are closed (at night, weekends and public holidays). The current pandemic has shown that existing on-call medical centers are no longer suited to caring for the growing number of patients, neither in the context of on-call care nor in times of health crisis.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Announced on December 24, 2020, The National Government opens on December 28, 2020, the first vaccination centre in the city of Luxembourg. It is located in the central part of the car park on the site of Halle Victor Hugo in Luxembourg-Limpertstberg. UPDATE: Originally, the vaccination centre at the Hall Victor Hugo in Limpertsberg was functioning normaly. Starting on January 3, 2022, the Hall Victor Hugo will be relocated to the Luxexpo The Box with access via the North public car park (main car park) - Hall 3C, due to technical problems at the former centre.

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

UPDATE: Originally, the vaccination centre at Luxexpo The Box (Luxembourg-Kirchberg) was opened due to technical problems at the vaccination centre the Hall Victor Hugo. description: On March 12th 2020 the National government of Luxembourg  mandated that the COVID-19 test is now reserved for serious or complicated cases. In this context, the concept of a risk zone is no longer relevant to define an indication for testing.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Health testing of entire population under the government's jurisdiction
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 26th 2020 the Luxembourg government announced the opening for four new advanced care centers with dual purpose: designed to accommodate patients with signs of COVID-19 infection AND designed to accommodate patients who come to the center with no signs of COVID-19 infection. Patients who are suspected by the physician of having COVID-19 infection are tested on site. If the test is positive, they are redirected according to their state of health. Either they can go home for self-isolation or they are transferred to a hospital structure in a specially equipped ambulance if their state of health requires it.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 8th 2020 the national government of Luxembourg announced that their COVID-19 task force launched a research project to test approximately 1500 people showing little or no signs to generate transmission data. Luxembourg Institute of Health will contact eligible participants directly to create a population sample that reflects the population makeup of the country. Currently not open to volunteers.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Announced on April 8, 2020, the Ministry of Higher Education and Research, together with the COVID-19 task force (Research Luxembourg initiative) launch the CON-VINCE, a scientific study aimed at assessing the dynamics of the spread of the virus in the Luxembourg population. The initiative will carry out screening tests on around1,500 people and to follow up on people with no or few symptoms (asymptomatic) and starts on April 8, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Education,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: The luxembourg government issued a tatment on May 22nd 2020 that large scale PCR testing calling on residents to volunteer when they receive an invitation. Invitations to be tested would be sent out by mail in three phases starting 25 May; phase 1 will include those working in personal care services.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Announced on May 22, 2020, The Luxembourg National Government and The Luxembourg Institute of Health (LIH) set out a large-scale testing 
project which will be operational from May 26, 2020, with a maximum capacity of 20,000 test per day. The goal of this large-scale testing is to identify possible positive Covid-19 cases and also asymptomatic people (PCR-testing order is divided into 3 categories). A  maximum of 17 "Drive-through" test stations and two "Walk- & Bike-through" test stations are distributed throughout Luxembourg to carry out this project.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Announced on June 22, 2020, the Luxembourg National Government that specially residents and cross-border workers have the chance to participate in the large-scale testing. Participants should apply through a online form. Then they will receive an invitation for the free PCR-Test, which will be taken in Examination Centers in question. The results are sent by SMS within two days after the collection of the samples.v

description: Announced on July 29, 2020, The Luxembourg National Government offers one free COVID-19 test per person ahead of a trip or stay abroad. This policy aims to facilitate Luxembourg residents obtain a COVID-19 test before their departure by making an appointment at one of the country’s testing centers, from July 31, 2020 onwards.

description: On August 18th 2020 the Luxembourg Government has made testing available for all travelers returning to Luxembourg from abroad, not just by plane. Travelers can sign up for a free test on MyGuichet.lu.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Announced on September 14, 2020, the Luxembourg Ministry of Health, together with the Minister of Higher Educational and Research and the COVID-19 Task Force of Research Luxembourg launched the second phase of the Large-Scale Testing.  7 fixed testing centers as well as mobile teams are responsible to test the participants with PCR and serological tests. The 5 priority groups of the LST are: first sampling tests (subgroups of resident and working population), second individuals particularly exposed (health personnel, nursing homes, CGDIS, etc), third “incoming travellers” and seasonal workers and finally the reactive tests.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Education,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:

Children can only be tested from 6 years onwards.
Opening hours: Monday-Sunday (10 a.m. to 5 p.m.).

description: The Ministry of Health states that From Friday, November 6, the National Health Laboratory (Laboratoire national de la santé - LNS) will open a COVID-19 Drive-in Sampling Centre at the LNS site in Dudelange, 1, rue Louis Rech. The tests are performed WITH an appointment, and only people with a medical prescription will be admitted. Children can only be tested from 6 years onwards. Appointments can be made via https://rdv.lns.lu/.

description:
As of 24 November 2020, the Medico-Social League offers, in collaboration with the National Health Laboratory (LNS) of Luxembourg, the possibility of doing a COVID-19 test (PCR test) for children between 2 and 6 years of age. Samples can be taken in the following medico-social centres:

CMS Luxembourg (2, rue G.C. Marshall; L-2181 Luxembourg)
CMS Ettelbruck (2A, avenue Lucien Salentiny; L-9080 Ettelbruck)
MS Dudelange (56, rue du Parc; L-3542 Dudelange)

description: Announced on March 11, 2021, the Luxembourg Ministry of Health and the Research Luxembourg Taskforce present the main axes of the Large-scale testing strategy 3. It begins on March 25, 2021 and ends on July 15, 2021. The strategy focus on increasing testing with PCR-test and nasopharyngeal ART among the population. Participants can be tested on fixed testing centers as well as mobile testing teams. The plan is divided into priority groups: 1. People with symptoms (doctors and health professionals in hospitals); 2. People which were identified by the contact tracing team, asymptomatic persons, specific sectors of activities in the country and then the general population; and 3. again hospitals, nursing homes, sports and culture sectors.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Asymptomatic people,Symptomatic people,Confirmed contact to a person infected with COVID-19

description: Ministry of Finance of Luxembourg states that egal persons and natural persons carrying out an activity generating trade and business income, agriculture and forestry income, or income from independent professional services, who are experiencing liquidity problems due to the Covid-19 pandemic, can apply for a cancellation of the two first quarterly advance tax payments of the year 2020. In addition, these same persons may request, for taxes due after 29 February 2020, a payment extension of four months.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_text: legal persons and natural persons carrying out an activity generating trade and business income, agriculture and forestry income, or income from independent professional services, who are experiencing liquidity problems due to the Covid-19 pandemic, can apply for a cancellation of the two first quarterly advance tax payments of the year 2020 (due in March and June 2020). Covered by this measure are (corporate) income and municipal business taxes.  In addition, these same persons may request, for taxes due after 29 February 2020, a payment extension of four months. On this deferral, no interest on late payment will be due and it covers (corporate) income, municipal business, and net wealth taxes. The main objective of these measures is to alleviate the financing and liquidity needs of corporations and self-employed persons strongly impacted by the current economic environment.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: the Joint Social Security Centre (CCSS) and the Ministry for Social Security of Luxembourg will pay an advance on the financial compensation for extraordinary leave for family reasons granted to the parents of children affected by the temporary closure of basic and secondary education, vocational training and childcare facilities as of 1 April 2020
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_text: an advance will be paid on the financial compensation for extraordinary leave for family reasons granted to the parents of children affected by the temporary closure of basic and secondary education, vocational training and childcare facilities. The purpose of this measure is to advance a substantial part of the reimbursement of salaries that employers must continue to pay to the parents concerned and which would normally only be made in May 2020 through the Employers' Mutual Insurance Scheme (Mutualité des Employeurs).  The CCSS will contact employers potentially affected by such extraordinary leaves for family reasons in order to provide them with the information necessary to request such an advance on the reimbursement of the Employers' Mutual Insurance Fund. The advance will be liquidated in mid-April 2020.

description: Announced on March 13, 2020, the Health Directorate of Luxembourg reminds the population that people with symptoms of an infection (cough, fever or breathing problems) should not go to the doctor or the emergency room, but should call the hotline number 8002 8080. It is also stated that vulnerable people should run errands outside of peak hours, if possible, postpone unnecessary trips, avoid mass events and avoid as much as possible public transport.

description: On Feb. 29, 2020, the government of Luxembourg announced procedures regarding the isolation of contact persons and the quarantine of infected persons. description: On Mar. 12, 2020, the government of Luxembourg announced binding rules for contact persons of confirmed corona-infected individuals. If a person had close contact to an infected person for a duration of over 15 minutes, the person is mandated to self-isolate for a duration of 7 days. UPDATE: The original requirement for contact persons to isolate for 7 days included no specific consequences for non-compliance. On Jul. 17., 2020, the government of Luxembourg announced that the violation of the self-isolation obligation will be punished with a fee ranging between 25 and 500 Euros. Furthermore, the duration of the quarantine can be decreased with a negative Covid-Test on the fifth day of the isolation period.

description: On Mar. 12, 2020, the government of Luxembourg announced binding rules for contact persons of confirmed corona-infected individuals. If a person had close contact to an infected person for a duration of over 15 minutes, the person is mandated to self-isolate for a duration of 7 days. UPDATE: The amended policy from July 17 allowed a reduction of the isolation period by 2 days if a contact person can show a negative Covid-Test after the fifth day of isolation. According to the new Covid law, which was adopted on September 23, a negative corona test can only lead to a decreased isolation period after the sixth day.

description: On March 15th 2021 the Luxembourg national government stated that a shutdown of non-essential businessess will begin. The policy applies to all but food and pharmacies, opticians, stores selling mainly pet food, telecommunication shops, stores selling mainly hygiene and washing products and sanitary equipment, sale of fuel and petrol stations, distributors and specialized trade in medical-sanitary equipment, medical pedicure, kiosks, dry-cleaning and laundry services, financial and insurance institutions, funeral services, the sale of non-food products in drive-ins, the sale of non-food products between professionals. This shutdown also applies to shops in supermarket shopping arcades, with the exception of the activities referred to above. The measures will come into effect on Mar 16, 2020 at midnight.

description:
Prime Minister of Luxembourg Xavier Bettel announced that bars, cafes and restaurants can reopen as of Friday 29 May 2020 for indoor seatings, and on 27 May 2020 for indoor seatings. 

Safety precautions: 
Guests have to be seated (they cannot stand at the bar), and there is a maximum of 4 people per table (unless they are from the same household);
Guests have to wear masks when they enter the venue or go to the bathroom, but not at the table;
A 2-metre distance must be maintained between tables
Restaurants can only open for bookings, so that reservations can be balanced to ensure the 2-metre distance.
Bars have to close at midnight.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: The Government of Luxembourg announced that Holiday activities offered between July 15 and September 15, 2020 by municipalities, relay houses, such as colonies and scout camps, may take place. The activities will be organized in groups of 50 children, supervised by a maximum of 10 facilitators. Within each group, covering the mouth and nose will no longer be necessary and children and young people will be able to interact normally. Activities will take place outside as much as possible. During contacts with outside people, reduced to a minimum, the usual rules will have to be respected.

description:
The national government of Luxembourg announced that starting from 25 July 2020 there will be sanctions reinforced for businesses. Customers may only be served if seated. Customers who do not observe this rule can be sanctioned.
The limit for people around a table is set at 10 people, unless the people come from the same household.
Wearing a mask is compulsory for customers when they are not seated at the table.
Wearing a mask is compulsory for staff who are in direct contact with customers.
Tables placed side by side must be separated by a distance of at least 1.5 metres or, in case of shorter distance, by a barrier or a physical separation to limit the risk of infection.
The closing time for restaurants, bars and cafés remains fixed at midnight.
 Penalties for businesses in violation of the rules have been increased. The basic fine of 4,000 euros may be doubled in the event of a repeat offence and the establishment's licence can be withdrawn for three months. In addition, these companies will not be eligible for government financial aid.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
The Ministry of Health and the Ministry of Sports states that If group lessons that do not formally fall under the scope of the practice of sports activities such as yoga, pilates, dance (non-sports), zumba etc. are organised, it is recommended to limit these to 4 actors + 1 supervisor, present simultaneously. Wearing a mask is then not compulsory for the actors, it remains however compulsory for the supervisor.

If the premises in which the courses are held are large enough and can be delimited into three distinct zones, it is possible to plan simultaneous activities of 3 groups of 4 actors in a closed place. For simultaneous outdoor activities, it is recommended to limit the activities to 6 groups of 4 actors (supervisors not included).

description:
On January 11th 2021 the government of Luxembourg announced that Shops, including non-essential shops, are open to all public. Various protective measures accompany this opening. A limit of one customer per 10m2 applies to all shops. However, small shops with a sales area of less than 20m2 can accommodate a maximum of two customers at the same time. Shopping centers with a sales area equal to or greater than 400m2 must, in addition, provide a health protocol, which has to be accepted by the National Health Directorate.  
Not wearing a mask in shops is punishable and customers may be refused.

description:
The government of Luxembourg announced that on June 13th 2021 Restaurants, bars, and cafés are open to the public both indoors and outdoors.  The accommodation of customers is subject to specific rules depending on the system under which these establishments choose to operate. Owners of restaurants, bars, and cafés can choose whether they want to opt for the CovidCheck system or not. The CovidCheck system is a system applicable to establishments (e.g. restaurants, bars, fitness centres, shops, etc.), events or gatherings (e.g. sporting events, concerts, etc.) open to the public, where entry is reserved exclusively for people (customers, spectators, staff, supervisors) who have been vaccinated, recovered or tested negative (either by means of an on-site self-test or by means of a certified negative result). 
Children under 6 years of age are exempt from performing an on-site self-test or presenting a COVID-19 test certificate. For those establishments that require CovidCheck, they operate without having to comply with special sanitary measures such as wearing a mask for staff in direct contact with customers or for customers themselves, and customers are no longer obliged to eat at the table and to respect the distance between tables. For those who decide not to opt for requiring CovidCheck, some protective measures such as mask-wearing and social distance are required.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
institution_cat: Non-Essential Businesses
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions

description:
The government of Luxembourg announced that on June 13th 2021 Restaurants, bars, and cafés are open to the public both indoors and outdoors.  The accommodation of customers is subject to specific rules depending on the system under which these establishments choose to operate. Owners of restaurants, bars, and cafés can choose whether they want to opt for the CovidCheck system or not. The CovidCheck system is a system applicable to establishments (e.g. restaurants, bars, fitness centres, shops, etc.), events or gatherings (e.g. sporting events, concerts, etc.) open to the public, where entry is reserved exclusively for people (customers, spectators, staff, supervisors) who have been vaccinated, recovered or tested negative (either by means of an on-site self-test or by means of a certified negative result). 
Children under 6 years of age are exempt from performing an on-site self-test or presenting a COVID-19 test certificate. For those establishments that require CovidCheck, they operate without having to comply with special sanitary measures such as wearing a mask for staff in direct contact with customers or for customers themselves, and customers are no longer obliged to eat at the table and to respect the distance between tables. For those who decide not to opt for requiring CovidCheck, some protective measures such as mask-wearing and social distance are required.

description:
The national government of Luxembourg announced on th 16th of July 2022 that Swimming pools and aquatic centres are open to the public. The capacity of the pools is limited to one person per 10m2. This means that swimming can be practised outside the lanes, and the use of leisure pools or other pools in aquatic centres as well as indoor and outdoor swimming pools is now possible.
Additionally, only a maximum of 10 people per locker room or collective shower area are allowed. In the locker rooms, people must either wear a mask or maintain a physical distance of 2 metres. In the showers, the physical distance of 2 metres must be respected. This does not apply for persons from the same household nor to school and extracurricular sports activities. 
These restrictions do not apply when sports and fitness activities are carried out under the CovidCheck system

description:
The national government of Luxembourg announced measures in force from 16 July 2021 onwards. For nightlife establishments the entry is limited to 300 people and CovidCheck certificate is required. 
If there are more than 300 people, application to the health directorate is required. 
After 1:00 am those who have not yet been vaccinated or are not recovered, need a PCR test (less than 72 hours old) or a certified rapid antigen test (less than 48 hours old)

description:
The national government of Luxembourg announced on the 16th of July 2021 that regarding sports: Young people under the age of 19 who belong to a sports club affiliated to an approved sports federation are also subject to a special regime. These young people can train under normal circumstances again and take part in competitions, provided they present a negative COVID-19 test.

The sports activities of young people under the age of 19 of clubs affiliated to sports federations are interrupted in the event of suspension of face-to-face classes and activities in fundamental and secondary education.

description:
The national government of Luxembourg announced on the 16th of July 2021 that elite athletes, as well as their training partners and coaches, professional athletes, athletes in federal national frameworks, students of the Sportslycée and federal training centres, licensed athletes practising a competitive team sport, licensed athletes practising an individual competitive sport and their coaches, are subject to a special regime. The sanitary restrictions that apply to the general public do not apply to these persons, both during training and during competitions.

In order to participate in sports competitions, each athlete and coach must present a rapid antigen test performed on site, with a negative result.

People who have been vaccinated, recovered or tested negative are exempted from such a test.

description:
Prime Minister of Luxembourg Xavier Bettel announced that bars, cafes and restaurants can reopen as of Friday 29 May 2020 for indoor seatings, and on 27 May 2020 for indoor seatings. 

Safety precautions: 
Guests have to be seated (they cannot stand at the bar), and there is a maximum of 4 people per table (unless they are from the same household);
Guests have to wear masks when they enter the venue or go to the bathroom, but not at the table;
A 2-metre distance must be maintained between tables
Restaurants can only open for bookings, so that reservations can be balanced to ensure the 2-metre distance.
Bars have to close at midnight.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From July 16th, the Luxembourgish government will render face masks mandatory for gatherings of more than 20 people, both in public and private settings. This rule applies if physical distance of 2m cannot be guaranteed while remaining seated. The policy is planned to end on September 30th.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The national government of Luxembourg announced that starting from 25 July 2020 there will be sanctions reinforced for businesses. Customers may only be served if seated. Customers who do not observe this rule can be sanctioned.
The limit for people around a table is set at 10 people, unless the people come from the same household.
Wearing a mask is compulsory for customers when they are not seated at the table.
Wearing a mask is compulsory for staff who are in direct contact with customers.
Tables placed side by side must be separated by a distance of at least 1.5 metres or, in case of shorter distance, by a barrier or a physical separation to limit the risk of infection.
The closing time for restaurants, bars and cafés remains fixed at midnight.
 Penalties for businesses in violation of the rules have been increased. The basic fine of 4,000 euros may be doubled in the event of a repeat offence and the establishment's licence can be withdrawn for three months. In addition, these companies will not be eligible for government financial aid.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The Ministry of Health and the Ministry of Sports states that If group lessons that do not formally fall under the scope of the practice of sports activities such as yoga, pilates, dance (non-sports), zumba etc. are organised, it is recommended to limit these to 4 actors + 1 supervisor, present simultaneously. Wearing a mask is then not compulsory for the actors, it remains however compulsory for the supervisor.

If the premises in which the courses are held are large enough and can be delimited into three distinct zones, it is possible to plan simultaneous activities of 3 groups of 4 actors in a closed place. For simultaneous outdoor activities, it is recommended to limit the activities to 6 groups of 4 actors (supervisors not included).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On January 11th 2021 the government of Luxembourg announced that Shops, including non-essential shops, are open to all public. Various protective measures accompany this opening. A limit of one customer per 10m2 applies to all shops. However, small shops with a sales area of less than 20m2 can accommodate a maximum of two customers at the same time. Shopping centers with a sales area equal to or greater than 400m2 must, in addition, provide a health protocol, which has to be accepted by the National Health Directorate.  
Not wearing a mask in shops is punishable and customers may be refused.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Shopping Centers
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Announced on February 12, 2021, The Luxembourg Minister of Education, Children and Youth allowed primary and secondary schools to open but under very strict conditions. For primary schools, It includes mandatory masks from students in the second cycle, there will be more testing, with everyone who was in quarantine requiring a test to return to school (antigen test). For secondary schools the pupils will return to alternate between two groups A/B schooling, exam schedules and study material for final years will be reduced of 15% and deadlines for final test will be adjusted.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)

date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)

description:
Announced on February 12, 2021, The Luxembourg Minister of Education, Children and Youth allowed primary and secondary schools to open but under very strict conditions. For primary schools, It includes mandatory masks from students in the second cycle, there will be more testing, with everyone who was in quarantine requiring a test to return to school (antigen test). For secondary schools the pupils will return to alternate between two groups A/B schooling, exam schedules and study material for final years will be reduced of 15% and deadlines for final test will be adjusted.
 UPDATE: Originally pupils of primary and secondary school have been alternating between face-to-face and/or distance learning courses. From May 31, 2021, the Ministry of National Education, Children and Youth of Luxembourg announces that classes from the secondary school will once again operate in whole classes face-to-face, although under the same conditions before: wearing masks.

description:
The government of Luxembourg announced that on June 13th 2021 Restaurants, bars, and cafés are open to the public both indoors and outdoors.  The accommodation of customers is subject to specific rules depending on the system under which these establishments choose to operate. Owners of restaurants, bars, and cafés can choose whether they want to opt for the CovidCheck system or not. The CovidCheck system is a system applicable to establishments (e.g. restaurants, bars, fitness centres, shops, etc.), events or gatherings (e.g. sporting events, concerts, etc.) open to the public, where entry is reserved exclusively for people (customers, spectators, staff, supervisors) who have been vaccinated, recovered or tested negative (either by means of an on-site self-test or by means of a certified negative result). 
Children under 6 years of age are exempt from performing an on-site self-test or presenting a COVID-19 test certificate. For those establishments that require CovidCheck, they operate without having to comply with special sanitary measures such as wearing a mask for staff in direct contact with customers or for customers themselves, and customers are no longer obliged to eat at the table and to respect the distance between tables. For those who decide not to opt for requiring CovidCheck, some protective measures such as mask-wearing and social distance are required.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People of a certain age (please note age range in the text entry),People who have recovered and/or survived COVID-19,People who are fully vaccinated against COVID-19,People who are partially vaccinated against COVID-19,People who are not vaccinated against COVID-19,People who are neither vaccinated nor recovered from COVID-19

description: The national government of Luxembourg announced from the 16th of July onwards sports of up to 10 people have no restrictions. From 10 people and more mask or 2m distance or CovidCheck enter in place. Also sport facilities must have a surface area of 10m2 per person practising sporting activity.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The national government of Luxembourg announced on th 16th of July 2022 that Swimming pools and aquatic centres are open to the public. The capacity of the pools is limited to one person per 10m2. This means that swimming can be practised outside the lanes, and the use of leisure pools or other pools in aquatic centres as well as indoor and outdoor swimming pools is now possible.
Additionally, only a maximum of 10 people per locker room or collective shower area are allowed. In the locker rooms, people must either wear a mask or maintain a physical distance of 2 metres. In the showers, the physical distance of 2 metres must be respected. This does not apply for persons from the same household nor to school and extracurricular sports activities. 
These restrictions do not apply when sports and fitness activities are carried out under the CovidCheck system
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Commercial Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
